The contraction mapping theorem is a powerful tool for analyzing general nonlinear equations. It is also known as the fixedpoint theorem.

  • Uniqueness: The fixed point x∗x^*x∗ is unique.

Proof

  • Part 1: Convergence of the Sequence

We prove that the sequence {xk}k=1∞\{x_{k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty}{xk​}k=1∞​ with xk=f(xk−1)x_{k}=f(x_{k-1})xk​=f(xk−1​) is convergent.

The proof relies on Cauchy sequences. A sequence x1,x2,⋯∈Rx_{1},x_{2},\cdots\in\mathbb{R}x1​,x2​,⋯∈R is called Cauchy if for any small ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0, there exists NNN such that ∥xm−xn∥<ε\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|<\varepsilon∥xm​−xn​∥<ε for all m,n>Nm,n>Nm,n>N. The intuitive interpretation is that there exists a finite integer NNN such that all the elements after NNN are sufficiently close to each other. Cauchy sequences are important because it is guaranteed that a Cauchy sequence converges to a limit. Its convergence property will be used to prove the contraction mapping theorem. Note that we must have ∥xm−xn∥<ε\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|<\varepsilon∥xm​−xn​∥<ε for all m,n>Nm,n>Nm,n>N. If we simply have xn+1−xn→0x_{n+1}-x_{n}\to 0xn+1​−xn​→0, it is insufficient to claim that the sequence is a Cauchy sequence. For example, it holds that xn+1−xn→0x_{n+1}-x_{n}\to 0xn+1​−xn​→0 for xn=nx_{n}=\sqrt{n}xn​=n​, but apparently, xn=nx_{n}=\sqrt{n}xn​=n​ diverges.

We next show that {xk=f(xk−1)}k=1∞\{x_{k}=f(x_{k-1})\}_{k=1}^{\infty}{xk​=f(xk−1​)}k=1∞​ is a Cauchy sequence and hence converges.

  • Part 2: Contraction Mapping Property

First, since fff is a contraction mapping, we have

∥xk+1−xk∥=∥f(xk)−f(xk−1)∥≤γ∥xk−xk−1∥.\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|=\|f(x_{k})-f(x_{k-1})\|\leq\gamma\|x_{k}-x_{k-1}\|. ∥xk+1​−xk​∥=∥f(xk​)−f(xk−1​)∥≤γ∥xk​−xk−1​∥.

Similarly, we have ∥xk−xk−1∥≤γ∥xk−1−xk−2∥,…, ∥x2−x1∥≤γ∥x1−x0∥\|x_{k}-x_{k-1}\|\leq\gamma\|x_{k-1}-x_{k-2}\|,\ldots,\,\|x_{2}-x_{1}\|\leq \gamma\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|∥xk​−xk−1​∥≤γ∥xk−1​−xk−2​∥,…,∥x2​−x1​∥≤γ∥x1​−x0​∥. Thus, we have

∥xk+1−xk∥≤γ∥xk−xk−1∥≤γ2∥xk−1−xk−2∥⋮≤γk∥x1−x0∥.\begin{aligned} \|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\| &\leq\gamma\|x_{k}-x_{k-1}\| \\ &\leq\gamma^{2}\|x_{k-1}-x_{k-2}\| \\ &\vdots \\ &\leq\gamma^{k}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|. \end{aligned} ∥xk+1​−xk​∥​≤γ∥xk​−xk−1​∥≤γ2∥xk−1​−xk−2​∥⋮≤γk∥x1​−x0​∥.​

Since γ<1\gamma<1γ<1, we know that ∥xk+1−xk∥\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|∥xk+1​−xk​∥ converges to zero exponentially fast as k→∞k\to\inftyk→∞ given any x1,x0x_{1},x_{0}x1​,x0​. Notably, the convergence of {∥xk+1−xk∥}\{\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|\}{∥xk+1​−xk​∥} is not sufficient for implying the convergence of {xk}\{x_{k}\}{xk​}. Therefore, we need to further consider ∥xm−xn∥\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|∥xm​−xn​∥ for any m>nm>nm>n. In particular,

∥xm−xn∥=∥xm−xm−1+xm−1−⋯−xn+1+xn+1−xn∥≤∥xm−xm−1∥+⋯+∥xn+1−xn∥≤γm−1∥x1−x0∥+⋯+γn∥x1−x0∥=γn(γm−1−n+⋯+1)∥x1−x0∥≤γn(1+⋯+γm−1−n+γm−n+γm−n+1+…)∥x1−x0∥=γn1−γ∥x1−x0∥.\begin{aligned} \|x_{m}-x_{n}\| &=\|x_{m}-x_{m-1}+x_{m-1}-\cdots-x_{n+1}+x_{n+1}-x_{n}\| \\ &\leq\|x_{m}-x_{m-1}\|+\cdots+\|x_{n+1}-x_{n}\| \\ &\leq\gamma^{m-1}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|+\cdots+\gamma^{n}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\| \\ &=\gamma^{n}(\gamma^{m-1-n}+\cdots+1)\|x_{1}-x_{0}\| \\ &\leq\gamma^{n}(1+\cdots+\gamma^{m-1-n}+\gamma^{m-n}+\gamma^{m-n+1}+\ldots)\|x_{1}-x_{0}\| \\ &=\frac{\gamma^{n}}{1-\gamma}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|. \quad \end{aligned} ∥xm​−xn​∥​=∥xm​−xm−1​+xm−1​−⋯−xn+1​+xn+1​−xn​∥≤∥xm​−xm−1​∥+⋯+∥xn+1​−xn​∥≤γm−1∥x1​−x0​∥+⋯+γn∥x1​−x0​∥=γn(γm−1−n+⋯+1)∥x1​−x0​∥≤γn(1+⋯+γm−1−n+γm−n+γm−n+1+…)∥x1​−x0​∥=1−γγn​∥x1​−x0​∥.​

As a result, for any ε\varepsilonε, we can always find NNN such that ∥xm−xn∥<ε\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|<\varepsilon∥xm​−xn​∥<ε for all m,n>Nm,n>Nm,n>N. Therefore, this sequence is Cauchy and hence converges to a limit point denoted as x∗=lim⁡k→∞xkx^{*}=\lim_{k\to\infty}x_{k}x∗=limk→∞​xk​.

  • Part 3: Fixed Point Property

We show that the limit x∗=lim⁡k→∞xkx^{*}=\lim_{k\to\infty}x_{k}x∗=limk→∞​xk​ is a fixed point. To do that, since

∥f(xk)−xk∥=∥xk+1−xk∥≤γk∥x1−x0∥,\|f(x_{k})-x_{k}\|=\|x_{k+1}-x_{k}\|\leq\gamma^{k}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|, ∥f(xk​)−xk​∥=∥xk+1​−xk​∥≤γk∥x1​−x0​∥,

we know that ∥f(xk)−xk∥\|f(x_{k})-x_{k}\|∥f(xk​)−xk​∥ converges to zero exponentially fast. Hence, we have f(x∗)=x∗f(x^{*})=x^{*}f(x∗)=x∗ at the limit.

  • Part 4: Uniqueness of the Fixed Point

We show that the fixed point is unique. Suppose that there is another fixed point x′x^{\prime}x′ satisfying f(x′)=x′f(x^{\prime})=x^{\prime}f(x′)=x′. Then,

∥x′−x∗∥=∥f(x′)−f(x∗)∥≤γ∥x′−x∗∥.\|x^{\prime}-x^{*}\|=\|f(x^{\prime})-f(x^{*})\|\leq\gamma\|x^{\prime}-x^{*}\|. ∥x′−x∗∥=∥f(x′)−f(x∗)∥≤γ∥x′−x∗∥.

Since γ<1\gamma<1γ<1, this inequality holds if and only if ∥x′−x∗∥=0\|x^{\prime}-x^{*}\|=0∥x′−x∗∥=0. Therefore, x′=x∗x^{\prime}=x^{*}x′=x∗.

  • Part 5: Exponential Convergence

We show that xhx_{h}xh​ converges to x∗x^{*}x∗ exponentially fast. Recall that ∥xm−xn∥≤γn1−γ∥x1−x0∥\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|\leq\frac{\gamma^{n}}{1-\gamma}\|x_{1}-x_{0}\|∥xm​−xn​∥≤1−γγn​∥x1​−x0​∥, as proven in (3.4). Since mmm can be arbitrarily large, we have

∥x∗−xn∥=lim⁡m→∞∥xm−xn∥≤γn1−γ∥x1−x0∥.\|x^{*}-x_{n}\|=\lim_{m\to\infty}\|x_{m}-x_{n}\|\leq\frac{\gamma^{n}}{1-\gamma} \|x_{1}-x_{0}\|. ∥x∗−xn​∥=m→∞lim​∥xm​−xn​∥≤1−γγn​∥x1​−x0​∥.

From State Value to Action Value

  • State value: The average return the agent can get starting from a state.
  • Action value: The average return the agent can get starting from a state and taking an action.

Why Do We Care About Action Value?

Because we want to know which action is better.

Definition of action value

The definition of action value is as follows：

qπ(s,a)=E[Gt∣St=s,At=a]q_{\pi}(s, a) = \mathbb{E}[G_t|S_t = s, A_t = a] qπ​(s,a)=E[Gt​∣St​=s,At​=a]

  • qπ(s,a)q_{\pi}(s, a)qπ​(s,a) is a function of the state-action pair (s,a)(s, a)(s,a)
  • qπ(s,a)q_{\pi}(s, a)qπ​(s,a) depends on π\piπ

Relationship between action value and state value

It follows from the properties of conditional expectation that

E[Gt∣St=s]⏟vπ(s)=∑a∈AtE[Gt∣St=s,At=a]π(a∣s)⏟qπ(s,a)\begin{aligned} \underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[G_t\mid S_t=s\right]}_{v_\pi(s)} = \sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}_t} \underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[G_t\mid S_t=s,A_t=a\right]\pi(a\mid s)}_{q_{\pi}(s,a)} \end{aligned} vπ​(s)E[Gt​∣St​=s]​​=a∈At​∑​qπ​(s,a)E[Gt​∣St​=s,At​=a]π(a∣s)​​​

Hence,

vπ(s)=∑aπ(a∣s)qπ(s,a)(1)\textcolor{hotpink}{v_{\pi}(s)} = \sum_a \pi(a|s)\textcolor{hotpink}{q_{\pi}(s, a)} \tag{1} vπ​(s)=a∑​π(a∣s)qπ​(s,a)(1)

Recall the Bellman equation, the state value is given by

vπ(s)=∑a∈Aπ(a∣s)[∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vπ(s′)]⏟qπ(s,a)v_{\pi}(s) = \sum_{a \in A} \pi(a | s) \underbrace{\left[ \sum_{r} p(r | s, a) r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s' | s, a) v_{\pi}(s') \right]}_{q_{\pi}(s,a)} vπ​(s)=a∈A∑​π(a∣s)qπ​(s,a)[r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,a)vπ​(s′)]​​

By comparing (1) and this equation, we have the action-value function as

qπ(s,a)=∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vπ(s′)(2)q_{\pi}(s, a) = \sum_{r} p(r | s, a) r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s' | s, a) v_{\pi}(s')\tag{2} qπ​(s,a)=r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,a)vπ​(s′)(2)

Remarks：

（1）and（2）are the two sides of the same coin：

  • （1）shows how to obtain state values from action values
  • （2）shows how to obtain action values from state values

Examples for action value

Consider the stochastic policy shown in the figure.

qπ(s1,a2)=−1+γvπ(s2)q_{\pi}(s_1, a_2) = -1 + \gamma v_{\pi}(s_2) qπ​(s1​,a2​)=−1+γvπ​(s2​)

Note that even if an action would not be selected by a policy, it still has an action value. Therefore, for the other actions:

qπ(s1,a1)=−1+γvπ(s1),qπ(s1,a3)=0+γvπ(s3),qπ(s1,a4)=−1+γvπ(s1),qπ(s1,a5)=0+γvπ(s1).\begin{aligned} q_{\pi}(s_1, a_1) &= -1 + \gamma v_{\pi}(s_1), \\ q_{\pi}(s_1, a_3) &= 0 + \gamma v_{\pi}(s_3), \\ q_{\pi}(s_1, a_4) &= -1 + \gamma v_{\pi}(s_1),\\ q_{\pi}(s_1, a_5) &= 0 + \gamma v_{\pi}(s_1). \end{aligned} qπ​(s1​,a1​)qπ​(s1​,a3​)qπ​(s1​,a4​)qπ​(s1​,a5​)​=−1+γvπ​(s1​),=0+γvπ​(s3​),=−1+γvπ​(s1​),=0+γvπ​(s1​).​

Highlights:

  • Action value is important since we care about which action to take.

  • We can first calculate all the state values and then calculate the action values.

  • We can also directly calculate the action values with or without models.

Bellman Optimality Equation, which is a special Bellman equation whose corresponding policy is optimal.

Optimal policy

The state value could be used to evaluate if a policy is good or not: if

vπ1(s)≥vπ2(s)v_{\pi_1}(s) \geq v_{\pi_2}(s) vπ1​​(s)≥vπ2​​(s)

Definition

A policy π∗\pi^*π∗ is optimal if

vπ∗(s)≥vπ(s)v_{\pi^*}(s) \geq v_{\pi}(s) vπ∗​(s)≥vπ​(s)

for all sss and for any other policy π\piπ.

The definition leads to many questions:

  • Does the optimal policy exist?
  • Is the optimal policy unique?
  • Is the optimal policy stochastic or deterministic?
  • How to obtain the optimal policy?

To answer these questions, introducing Bellman optimality equation.

Bellman Optimality Equation（BOE）

The BOE is the tool to analyze optimal state values and optimal policies. Two forms of BOE are as follows:

Elementwise form

v(s)=max⁡π(s)∈Π(s)(E[Rt+1∣St=s]+γE[Gt+1∣St=s])=max⁡π(s)∈Π(s)∑a∈Aπ(a∣s)(∑r∈Rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′∈Sp(s′∣s,a)v(s′))=max⁡π(s)∈Π(s)∑a∈Aπ(a∣s)q(s,a),\begin{aligned} v(s) &= \max_{\pi(s) \in \Pi(s)} \left( \mathbb{E} \left[ R_{t+1} \mid S_t = s \right] + \gamma \mathbb{E} \left[ G_{t+1} \mid S_t = s \right] \right)\\ &= \max_{\pi(s) \in \Pi(s)} \sum_{a \in A} \pi(a \mid s) \left( \sum_{r \in R} p(r \mid s, a) r + \gamma \sum_{s' \in S} p\left(s' \mid s, a\right) v\left(s'\right) \right)\\ &= \max_{\pi(s) \in \Pi(s)} \sum_{a \in A} \pi(a \mid s) q(s, a), \end{aligned} v(s)​=π(s)∈Π(s)max​(E[Rt+1​∣St​=s]+γE[Gt+1​∣St​=s])=π(s)∈Π(s)max​a∈A∑​π(a∣s)(r∈R∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∈S∑​p(s′∣s,a)v(s′))=π(s)∈Π(s)max​a∈A∑​π(a∣s)q(s,a),​
